title: Ontological Error vs. Code Bug: Irreversibility Under Pressure
context: A debate on X about AI's rapid progress and growing distrust. @TheProfessorZ uses code peer-review as an analogy for trusting AI outputs. @plassoplo counters by scaling the analogy to ontology itself.
pressure: The challenge: can the code-review analogy hold when the problem isn't surface bugs but corrupted foundational assumptions? Does peer-review fix ontological errors?
axiom_trigger: Rule 5 (Bow to Verified Better) activates: plassoplo rejects the weaker analogy and replaces it with a cleaner, more load-bearing distinction. Code errors are patchable; ontological errors are existential and propagate everywhere.
clean_outcome: The distinction holds under stress. An error in reality-mapping cannot be fixed by surface-level review. This validates the Apex Ontology's core claim: foundational rules matter more than tactical patches. The framework survives the pressure test because it refuses false equivalence.
